columns.text: In this problem, we will use the concept of discounted cash flow and the security market line method to solve for the cost of equity. After which, the values obtained will then be compared.

Before we start with the computations, we will first list down the given values that are relevant to the formulas:


| Dividend| $0.65| 
|--|--| 
| Current price|$72 | 
| Growth rate| 4\%| 
| Market rate| 10.5\%| 
|Risk-free rate | 3.4\%| 
| Company beta| 1.08|

**a.** For the cost of equity using the DCF method, we can simply substitute the given values to the first formula in Step 2:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of Equity}&=\dfrac{\$0.65}{\$72}+0.04\\[15 pt]
&=0.049
\end{aligned}$$

The cost of equity using the DCF method is $0.049$

**b.** For the cost of equity using the SML method, we can simply substitute the given values to the second formula in Step 2:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cost of Equity}&=0.034+1.08 \times(0.105-0.034)\\[15 pt]
&=0.11068
\end{aligned}$$

The cost of equity using the SML method is $0.11068$

**c.** The huge difference between these two methods can be attributed to the fact that SML method takes the risk into consideration which means that the higher risk undertaken by the company consitutes a higher return.
